abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment shows highly
            unsatisfactory project outcomes, with highly unlikely
            sustainability, and negligible institutional development
            impacts. Regrettably, both performances by the Bank, and
            Borrower were also rated unsatisfactory. Lessons stipulate
            that: 1) major changes in fundamental project financial
            responsibilities MUST automatically trigger reappraisal; 2)
            supervision resources for the initial first two years of a
            new Bank project, are directly related to the quality of
            project implementation, as procurement procedures, covenant
            enforcement seriousness, and project ownership are
            established during such period. Unfortunately in this case,
            this was a major failure by the Bank; 3) the Bank must work
            with the Government of Indonesia to improve the legal,
            regulatory and policy frameworks governing land acquisition
            for public purposes - and preferably, on broader work on
            land tenure, and rights, as well as dispute resolution
            mechanisms, as envisioned under the upcoming Second Land
            Administration Project; and, 4) technical audits should
            become part of future projects, demonstrated by the
            usefulness of such audits in this project, though the
            Government, and all other participants failed to follow up
            on any of the findings. Further lessons recommend
            assessments of external shocks; improved enforcement of loan
            covenants; improved provisions for public information,
            namely for cases of fraud, and corruption; and, question the
            appropriateness of parallel financing arrangements for
            complex, integrated operations, such as this one.
